Additional metadata: Crew member (ship's cooper) on the Mayflower who chose to remain at Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}. Signer of the Mayflower Compact and later a prominent official in Plymouth Colony. Married fellow passenger Priscilla Mullins and had ten children​:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}​:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.

Deputy Governor of Plymouth Colony and merchant​:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}. He was a Leiden Separatist who brought his family on the Mayflower. After his first wife Mary died, he remarried twice and later moved to New Amsterdam and New Haven, where he died​:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.
Wife of Isaac Allerton​:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}. She died during the first winter in Plymouth (on 25 February 1621)​:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

Son of Isaac and Mary Allerton​:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}. He returned to England, married, and had children there. He was still living in England as of 1650​:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

Daughter of Isaac and Mary Allerton​:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}. Married Moses Maverick of Salem by 1635​:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}. She remained in the Massachusetts Bay area; her exact death date is unknown.

Youngest daughter of Isaac Allerton​:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. She married Thomas Cushman and died in 1699, becoming the last surviving Mayflower passenger​:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}.

Mayflower seaman hired as labor for the colony​:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}. Not known to be related to the Allerton family. Died during the first winter in Plymouth (between January and April 1621)​:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}.

A dissident among the colonists (one of the "strangers"). He was executed by hanging in September 1630 for murder​:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}, becoming the colony’s first criminal to be executed.

Wife of John Billington​:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}. She survived the first winter and remarried (to Gregory Armstrong in 1638) after John’s execution​:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}. She was still alive as of 1643.

Elder son of John and Eleanor Billington​:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. Born about 1604, he died sometime between 1627 and 1630 in Plymouth, unmarried​:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}.

Younger son of John Billington​:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}. Born about 1606, he survived to adulthood and married Christian (Penn) Eaton (widow of Mayflower passenger Francis Eaton) in 1634​:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}. He died in December 1684 in Middleboro, MA​:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.

Leiden Separatist and Mayflower passenger who became longtime Governor of Plymouth Colony​:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}. Baptized 19 March 1590 in Austerfield, Yorkshire​:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}, he authored *Of Plymouth Plantation*. He died on 9 May 1657 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}.

Wife of William Bradford​:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}. She fell overboard from the Mayflower and drowned in Cape Cod Harbor in December 1620, while the ship was anchored off Cape Cod​:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}.

Elder of the Pilgrim church and spiritual leader of the colony​:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}. Born 1566/1567 in Scrooby, England​:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}, he died 10 April 1644 in Duxbury​:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}. He was a senior Separatist who provided religious guidance in Plymouth.

Wife of William Brewster​:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}. Her maiden name is unknown. One of only five adult women to survive the first winter, she died on 17 April 1627 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}.

Son of William and Mary Brewster​:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}. Born about 1607–1611, likely in Leiden, he married Sarah Collier in 1634​:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}. He died in late 1650 or early 1651 in Duxbury​:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}.

Youngest son of William Brewster​:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}, about 9 years old in 1620. He died unmarried sometime between 1627 and 1651​:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37} (alive in 1627, but dead by 1651).

A young single man, one of the Mayflower Compact signers. He died on 21 December 1620, becoming the first passenger to die after the Mayflower reached New England (Cape Cod Harbor)​:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}.

A single man from England. Born by about 1600​:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}, he signed the Mayflower Compact and later married twice in Plymouth. He died in 1633 during an epidemic in the colony​:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}.

Youthful servant of Samuel Fuller​:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}. He died at sea as the Mayflower was nearing the New England coast in November 1620​:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}, just before landfall.
Servant of William Mullins​:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}. He died during the first winter in Plymouth (1620–21)​:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}.

First governor of Plymouth Colony​:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}. Born by 1580–85, he was instrumental in organizing the voyage. He died suddenly in April 1621, only a few months after becoming governor​:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}, leaving no surviving children.

Wife of Governor John Carver​:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}. She died about five or six weeks after her husband (around May 1621)​:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}. Bradford noted they had no surviving children (two children died in Leiden earlier).

At about 64, he was the oldest Mayflower passenger​:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}. A tailor from Canterbury, he died aboard the Mayflower in Cape Cod Harbor around 8 December 1620, before the Pilgrims moved ashore​:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}.

Wife of James Chilton. Her first name and maiden name are not recorded​:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}. She died in the early months of 1621, shortly after the landing (sometime after 11 January 1621)​:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}.

Daughter of James Chilton​:contentReference[oaicite:53]{index=53}. Tradition holds she was the first woman to step ashore at Plymouth Rock. Baptized in 1607​:contentReference[oaicite:54]{index=54}, she married John Winslow (brother of Edward) in Plymouth and died in 1679 in Boston​:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}.
A single man and signer of the Mayflower Compact. He died during the first winter (the "general sickness") soon after arrival​:contentReference[oaicite:56]{index=56}.

A Leiden Separatist (a woolcomber by trade)​:contentReference[oaicite:57]{index=57}. Born in or shortly after 1583​:contentReference[oaicite:58]{index=58}, he traveled with his teenage son John while his wife Hester and other children came later. He died 7 April 1663 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:59]{index=59}.

Son of Francis Cooke​:contentReference[oaicite:60]{index=60}, baptized in Leiden in 1607​:contentReference[oaicite:61]{index=61}. He married Sarah Warren (daughter of Richard Warren) in 1634​:contentReference[oaicite:62]{index=62}. A prominent settler of Dartmouth, he lived until 23 November 1695, making him one of the last surviving male Mayflower passengers​:contentReference[oaicite:63]{index=63}.

Infant niece of Edward and Ann Tilley​:contentReference[oaicite:64]{index=64}. About 1 year old on the voyage, she was sent back to England by 1651 and died there unmarried​:contentReference[oaicite:65]{index=65}.

An older Separatist from Leiden. He died during the first winter (between January and April 1621) in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:66]{index=66}. His wife likely died before 1620, and a daughter stayed behind in Leiden​:contentReference[oaicite:67]{index=67}.
Son of John Crackston Sr., a teenager in 1620. He died around 1627 in Plymouth, reportedly after getting lost in the woods and suffering exposure (frostbite)​:contentReference[oaicite:68]{index=68}.

Servant to Stephen Hopkins​:contentReference[oaicite:69]{index=69} and signer of the Mayflower Compact. Born about 1599​:contentReference[oaicite:70]{index=70}, he later became a freeman and settler in Plymouth. Notorious for fighting a duel in 1621, he went on to marry Faith Clarke and had nine children​:contentReference[oaicite:71]{index=71}. He died 23 August 1655 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:72]{index=72}.

A carpenter from Bristol, he signed the Mayflower Compact​:contentReference[oaicite:73]{index=73}. His first wife Sarah died in the first winter​:contentReference[oaicite:74]{index=74}. He remarried twice (his second wife, perhaps Carver’s former maid, died around 1623; his third wife Christian Penn survived him)​:contentReference[oaicite:75]{index=75}. Eaton died in the autumn of 1633 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:76]{index=76}.

First wife of Francis Eaton​:contentReference[oaicite:77]{index=77}. She traveled on the Mayflower with Francis and their baby Samuel. She died early in 1621 during the general sickness (first winter)​:contentReference[oaicite:78]{index=78}.

Infant son of Francis and Sarah Eaton ("a sucking child" on the Mayflower)​:contentReference[oaicite:79]{index=79}. Born late 1619 or 1620, he later moved to Middleboro, where he died in 1684​:contentReference[oaicite:80]{index=80}. He married twice (Elizabeth ___, then Martha Billington) in the 1640s–1660s​:contentReference[oaicite:81]{index=81}.
Hired crewman designated to be the shallop pilot for the colony​:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82}. He died during the first winter in early 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:83]{index=83}.

A Separatist from Leiden (originally from England)​:contentReference[oaicite:84]{index=84}. Born by 1565, he was a widower with many grown children. He died in the first winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:85]{index=85}, leaving no descendants in the colony.

Passenger from Leiden (brother of Dr. Samuel Fuller)​:contentReference[oaicite:86]{index=86}. Baptized in 1575 in Redenhall, England​:contentReference[oaicite:87]{index=87}. He and his wife died during the first winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:88]{index=88}, orphaning their 12-year-old son Samuel.

Wife of Edward Fuller​:contentReference[oaicite:89]{index=89}. Her first name and maiden name are unknown. She died with her husband during the first winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:90]{index=90}.

Son of Edward Fuller​:contentReference[oaicite:91]{index=91}, about 12 years old in 1620. After his parents died, he was raised by his uncle Dr. Samuel Fuller. He married Jane Lothrop in 1635​:contentReference[oaicite:92]{index=92} and later settled in Barnstable, where he died 31 October 1683​:contentReference[oaicite:93]{index=93}.

A Leiden Separatist and the colony’s doctor​:contentReference[oaicite:94]{index=94}. Baptized 20 January 1580 at Redenhall, Norfolk​:contentReference[oaicite:95]{index=95}, he served as the physician and a deacon in Plymouth. He died between 9 August and 26 September 1633 in an epidemic in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:96]{index=96}.

A former sailor who signed the Compact. He survived the first winter and later left Plymouth to return to the sea. He was alive in 1623 (received land) but is noted by Bradford as having died overseas sometime afterward​:contentReference[oaicite:97]{index=97}.

A young, single colonist and Compact signer. He died during the first winter (1620/21) in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:98]{index=98}. Although he briefly appeared in the 1623 land division, he was dead by 1627​:contentReference[oaicite:99]{index=99}.
Servant to William White​:contentReference[oaicite:100]{index=100}. He died shortly after the Mayflower landed, during the winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:101]{index=101}.
Teenage servant of Isaac Allerton​:contentReference[oaicite:102]{index=102}. He died in the early months of 1621 during the first winter in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:103]{index=103}.

Second wife of Stephen Hopkins​:contentReference[oaicite:104]{index=104}. She traveled with him and their young children. She died in Plymouth in the early 1640s (before 1644)​:contentReference[oaicite:105]{index=105}.

Son of Stephen Hopkins by his first marriage​:contentReference[oaicite:106]{index=106}. Baptized 30 January 1608​:contentReference[oaicite:107]{index=107}, he married Catherine Wheldon in 1639​:contentReference[oaicite:108]{index=108}. He settled in Eastham and died between March 1689 and April 1690​:contentReference[oaicite:109]{index=109}.

Daughter of Stephen Hopkins by his first marriage​:contentReference[oaicite:110]{index=110}. Baptized 11 May 1606​:contentReference[oaicite:111]{index=111}, she married Nicholas Snow in Plymouth by 1627​:contentReference[oaicite:112]{index=112}. They had a large family and moved to Eastham; Constance died in October 1677​:contentReference[oaicite:113]{index=113}.

Daughter of Stephen and Elizabeth Hopkins, about 2 years old in 1620. She died sometime before 1628 (a later daughter born around 1628 was also named Damaris, indicating this first Damaris had died)​:contentReference[oaicite:114]{index=114}.

Newborn son of Stephen and Elizabeth Hopkins, born aboard the Mayflower en route in 1620​:contentReference[oaicite:115]{index=115}. He survived the voyage but died in childhood, before 1627​:contentReference[oaicite:116]{index=116}.

Manservant to Governor John Carver and a signatory of the Compact​:contentReference[oaicite:117]{index=117}. Born about 1592, he famously was swept overboard during the voyage but was rescued​:contentReference[oaicite:118]{index=118}. He married fellow passenger Elizabeth Tilley and had ten children​:contentReference[oaicite:119]{index=119}. He died 23 February 1673 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:120]{index=120}.
Servant to Christopher Martin​:contentReference[oaicite:121]{index=121}. He died during the first winter (the "first sickness") in early 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:122]{index=122}.

Boy servant in John Carver’s household​:contentReference[oaicite:123]{index=123}. He stayed in the colony about twenty years, then returned to England and later went to the Bahamas, where he reportedly starved to death for lack of food​:contentReference[oaicite:124]{index=124}.

Servant to Stephen Hopkins​:contentReference[oaicite:125]{index=125}. After completing his term of service, he left Plymouth and went to Virginia, where he eventually died (sometime before 1650)​:contentReference[oaicite:126]{index=126}.
A single man who died during the first winter in Plymouth (early 1621)​:contentReference[oaicite:127]{index=127}. He left no known descendants.

He was the Mayflower’s provisioner and a Leiden Separatist financial agent​:contentReference[oaicite:128]{index=128}. Baptized in Great Burstead in 1582, he traveled with his wife and stepson. He fell ill and died on January 8, 1621, during the first winter​:contentReference[oaicite:129]{index=129}.

Wife of Christopher Martin​:contentReference[oaicite:130]{index=130} (widow of _____ Prower before marriage to Martin). She died during the first winter of 1620/21 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:131]{index=131}.

A young woman under the care of the Carvers on the voyage​:contentReference[oaicite:132]{index=132}. She returned to England a few years later (before 1627) due to illness and died there, with no husband or children​:contentReference[oaicite:133]{index=133}.

One of the four More children sent on the Mayflower​:contentReference[oaicite:134]{index=134}. About 8 years old, she was placed with Edward Winslow’s family. She died early in 1621 during the first winter​:contentReference[oaicite:135]{index=135}.

One of the More children, about 7 years old. He was placed with John Carver’s family and died aboard the Mayflower in Cape Cod Harbor on 16 December 1620​:contentReference[oaicite:136]{index=136}, before the Pilgrims settled on land.

One of the four More siblings and the only one to survive​:contentReference[oaicite:137]{index=137}. Baptized 13 November 1614​:contentReference[oaicite:138]{index=138}, he was about 5–6 years old in 1620. He later became a sea captain and settled in Salem. He died between March 1694 and April 1696 in Salem​:contentReference[oaicite:139]{index=139}.

One of the More children (Richard’s sister)​:contentReference[oaicite:140]{index=140}. About 4 years old on the Mayflower, she died during the first winter in early 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:141]{index=141}.

A merchant shoemaker from Dorking​:contentReference[oaicite:142]{index=142}. He traveled with his wife and two of their children (Priscilla and Joseph). He died on 21 February 1621 during the first winter​:contentReference[oaicite:143]{index=143}, after drafting a will that survives. (Two older children remained in England.)
Wife of William Mullins​:contentReference[oaicite:144]{index=144}. She died in the first winter of 1621, sometime after 2 April 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:145]{index=145}.

Daughter of William Mullins​:contentReference[oaicite:146]{index=146}. About 17 years old in 1620, she lost her parents and brother the first winter. She married John Alden by 1623​:contentReference[oaicite:147]{index=147} and had a large family. She died around 1685 and is buried in Duxbury​:contentReference[oaicite:148]{index=148}.

Son of William Mullins​:contentReference[oaicite:149]{index=149}. He traveled with his parents and sister Priscilla. Born about 1596, he died in Plymouth during the first winter, after 2 April 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:150]{index=150}.

A Leiden Separatist. Born about 1579, he married Sarah (Allerton) in Leiden in 1611​:contentReference[oaicite:151]{index=151}. He died on 1 January 1621 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:152]{index=152}. His wife (sister of Isaac Allerton) and daughters stayed behind and came in 1623.

Servant in the Christopher Martin family​:contentReference[oaicite:153]{index=153} (possibly Mary Martin’s son from her first marriage). He died during the first winter of 1620/21 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:154]{index=154}.
Passenger from London (possibly). He and his wife Alice both died during the first winter of 1620/21 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:155]{index=155}.
Wife of John Rigdale​:contentReference[oaicite:156]{index=156}. She died in the first winter of 1620/21, along with her husband, leaving no surviving family in the colony.

A merchant from Leiden, originally from Northamptonshire​:contentReference[oaicite:157]{index=157}. He brought his teenage son Joseph on the Mayflower; his wife and other children stayed in Leiden. He died soon after arrival in the winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:158]{index=158}.

Son of Thomas Rogers​:contentReference[oaicite:159]{index=159}, baptized 23 January 1603​:contentReference[oaicite:160]{index=160}. He survived the first winter as a teen. He married by 1633 and settled in Eastham. He died in early 1678 in Eastham​:contentReference[oaicite:161]{index=161}.

Child passenger, nephew of the Tilleys​:contentReference[oaicite:162]{index=162}. Baptized 15 January 1604 in Henlow​:contentReference[oaicite:163]{index=163}, he was about 16 in 1620. He later married Anne Plummer in 1636 and settled in Duxbury. He died between December 1684 and March 1685​:contentReference[oaicite:164]{index=164}.

Servant to Edward Winslow​:contentReference[oaicite:165]{index=165} (later a freeman). He married Mary Buckett in Plymouth by 1626. He died between 20 September 1677 and 22 January 1680 in Duxbury​:contentReference[oaicite:166]{index=166}. (His will was probated in 1680.)

A professional soldier hired as military adviser for the Pilgrims​:contentReference[oaicite:167]{index=167}. Born ca. 1584 in Lancashire​:contentReference[oaicite:168]{index=168}, he led the colony’s militia. He was a signatory of the Compact and served as Plymouth’s military captain until his death on 3 October 1656 in Duxbury​:contentReference[oaicite:169]{index=169}.

Wife of Captain Myles Standish​:contentReference[oaicite:170]{index=170}. She died in January 1621, within weeks of the landing, during the first winter at Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:171]{index=171}.
Servant in the Winslow household​:contentReference[oaicite:172]{index=172}. He died shortly after arrival in the winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:173]{index=173}.
Servant to William White​:contentReference[oaicite:174]{index=174}. He died shortly after the Mayflower landed, in December 1620 or early 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:175]{index=175}.

A London leather-dresser and Separatist, baptized 27 May 1588 in Henlow​:contentReference[oaicite:176]{index=176}. He traveled with his wife Ann and two young relatives (Humility Cooper and Henry Samson). Edward and Ann both died shortly after arrival in the winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:177]{index=177}.

Wife of Edward Tilley​:contentReference[oaicite:178]{index=178} (and aunt of Humility Cooper and Henry Samson). She died in the first winter of 1620/21, soon after reaching Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:179]{index=179}.

Baptized 19 December 1571 in Henlow​:contentReference[oaicite:180]{index=180}, elder brother of Edward Tilley. He came with his wife Joan and daughter Elizabeth. John and Joan both died during the first winter in early 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:181]{index=181}.

Wife of John Tilley​:contentReference[oaicite:182]{index=182}. She had five children (four left in England). She died soon after arrival in early 1621, along with her husband, leaving their 13-year-old daughter Elizabeth an orphan​:contentReference[oaicite:183]{index=183}.

Daughter of John and Joan Tilley​:contentReference[oaicite:184]{index=184}, baptized 30 August 1607​:contentReference[oaicite:185]{index=185}. She married fellow passenger John Howland by 1625 and had ten children​:contentReference[oaicite:186]{index=186}. She lived to 22 December 1687, dying in Swansea, Massachusetts at age 80​:contentReference[oaicite:187]{index=187}.

A carpenter from Holland (Leiden Separatist). He, his wife, and their young son all died in the "first sickness" during the winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:188]{index=188}​:contentReference[oaicite:189]{index=189}.
Wife of Thomas Tinker. Traveled with her husband and son and died in the first winter of 1620/21 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:190]{index=190}.
Young son of Thomas Tinker. He died with his parents during the first winter of 1620/21 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:191]{index=191}.

Widower from Leiden who traveled with his two young sons. He died in the first winter of 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:192]{index=192}. (He had a daughter who stayed behind and came to Salem in 1629​:contentReference[oaicite:193]{index=193}.)
Son of John Turner. He died during the first winter of 1620/21 in Plymouth, along with his father and brother​:contentReference[oaicite:194]{index=194}.
Youngest son of John Turner. He also perished during the first winter in Plymouth in 1620/21​:contentReference[oaicite:195]{index=195}.

A merchant from London who joined the Mayflower at Southampton. He signed the Compact. His wife Elizabeth and five daughters remained in England and came on a later ship in 1623​:contentReference[oaicite:196]{index=196}. He died in 1628 in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:197]{index=197}, leaving seven children in all.

A Leiden Separatist. He traveled with his pregnant wife Susanna and young son Resolved. He signed the Compact. William died on 21 February 1621 during the first winter in Plymouth​:contentReference[oaicite:198]{index=198}.

Wife of William White​:contentReference[oaicite:199]{index=199}, and one of only four Pilgrim women to survive the first winter​:contentReference[oaicite:200]{index=200}. After William’s death, she remarried Edward Winslow on 12 May 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:201]{index=201} – the first wedding in Plymouth. She died sometime after 1654 (likely by 1675) in Marshfield​:contentReference[oaicite:202]{index=202}.

Elder son of William and Susanna White​:contentReference[oaicite:203]{index=203}, about 5 years old during the voyage. He married Judith Vassall in 1640​:contentReference[oaicite:204]{index=204} and later moved to Marshfield. He was living in 1687 (records show he was alive as of 19 September 1687)​:contentReference[oaicite:205]{index=205}.

Son of William and Susanna White, born aboard the Mayflower in late November 1620 while it was anchored off Cape Cod​:contentReference[oaicite:206]{index=206}. The first English child born in New England, he later became a farmer and captain of the militia. He married Sarah Bassett and had children​:contentReference[oaicite:207]{index=207}. He lived to age 83, dying 20 July 1704 in Marshfield​:contentReference[oaicite:208]{index=208}.
Manservant in John Carver’s household​:contentReference[oaicite:209]{index=209}. He died during the first year in Plymouth (likely the winter of 1620/21)​:contentReference[oaicite:210]{index=210}.
One of the Mayflower Compact signers. He died shortly after arrival in the sickness of the first winter (early 1621)​:contentReference[oaicite:211]{index=211}. Little else is known of him.

A prominent Pilgrim leader. Baptized 20 October 1595 in Droitwich​:contentReference[oaicite:212]{index=212}, he served as Assistant and three-time Governor of Plymouth. His first wife died the first winter; he famously married Susanna White in May 1621​:contentReference[oaicite:213]{index=213}. Winslow later served in Oliver Cromwell’s expedition to the Caribbean and died at sea near Jamaica on 8 May 1655​:contentReference[oaicite:214]{index=214}.

First wife of Edward Winslow​:contentReference[oaicite:215]{index=215}. They married in Leiden. She died in Plymouth on 24 March 1621 during the first winter​:contentReference[oaicite:216]{index=216}.

Younger brother of Edward Winslow​:contentReference[oaicite:217]{index=217}. Baptized 29 October 1600​:contentReference[oaicite:218]{index=218}, he signed the Mayflower Compact. After several years in Plymouth, he returned to England between 1623 and 1627 and died there before 1660 (in Portsmouth)​:contentReference[oaicite:219]{index=219}.

Full Name: Unknown Maidservant of the Carver family
Additional metadata: A young female servant of John Carver’s household​:contentReference[oaicite:220]{index=220}. Her name is not recorded. Some evidence suggests she survived the first winter and later married Francis Eaton as his second wife​:contentReference[oaicite:221]{index=221}, dying a year or two afterward (by 1623).
